title: GPT-4 Just Released. Here's What You Need To Know.
description:
Here are the main points from GPT-4's release. What's flying under the radar are all the implications for business applications and intelligent agents. In this video, I break down some of the applications that were announced with GPT-4 and explain where we are going next.

Data teams are about to get inundated with requests to integrate GPT-4 into everything, and it's critical to keep the high-value opportunities while avoiding the hype-driven ones.

If you need help developing a GPT-4 Monetization and Product Strategy, I've got you covered in this, self-paced course:
https://highroidatascience.teachable.com/p/partnering-with-ai-monetizing-large-models-like-chatgpt

I explain the frameworks you'll need for opportunity discovery and product design. It will help you get ahead of the curve and ahead of competitors.

title: Is GPT The End Of Data Scientists?
description:
Is this the end of data science teams for most businesses? Will large models replace us? My answer will surprise you. I think a lot of data science teams will be disrupted. They’ve overpromised, and GPT has revealed the deep learning long con.

Data scientists aren’t going away completely. The role will continue to be a value creator with a new focus. I think this will be great for our field, but there will be some pain ahead for many teams.

If you like my videos, you’ll get even more from my courses. Take a look at the entire catalog here: https://www.datascience.vin/courses

title: Quiet Firing Is The Next Layoff Wave. How Companies Are Retitling Data Professionals.
description:
Layoffs are slowing in December but a new wave will ramp up in January. Data professionals are in high demand, but businesses don't need the same team composition.

They've started "Quiet Firing" employees by closing positions and giving those impacted 60-90 days to apply for a different role. Most roles are at a lower level and the requirements to maintain their current role have jumped.

Here's what you need to know and what to do about this next wave.

title: Why Do Companies Lay People Off? I'll Explain WHY These 12 Companies Cut Staff This Week.
description:
I’ll use 12 companies that cut staff this week to explain why companies lay people off so you know what to look for. In my last videos, I explained the big picture, so in this video, it’s time to do a deep dive with specific examples.

I will cover these 12 companies:
1. Amazon
2. Tencent
3. Stripe
4. iFit
5. Cisco
6. Roku
7. CNN
8. FedEx
9. Juniper
10. Disney Plus
11. Asana
12. UiPath

There’s more to learn on my Substack newsletter: https://vinvashishta.substack.com/

title: Resumes Stand Out By Doing 5 Things Most Job Seekers Don't Know About. Here's What They Are.
description:
A company was about to pay me $3000 for a resume-building series. The deal fell through, so now it’s yours for free.

Most resumes do more to confuse recruiters and hiring managers than to explain the candidate’s capabilities. They lack consistent themes for readers to connect with. That makes them hard to read and more likely to end up at the bottom of the pile.

Capable people get overlooked because their resume doesn’t tell the story of the value they can create and the problems they solve. In this video, I’ll explain a different process for resume building. By starting with simple themes and working forward from those, you’ll write a resume that targets decision-making. The result will be more interviews and phone screens.

This is the overview, and I need you to comment and tell me what else you want to know or have me dive into with greater detail.

There's more content to explore on Substack: https://vinvashishta.substack.com/

title: Recession Proofing Your Data Career. Data Product Management.
description:
Data Product Managers will be impacted least by layoffs. Why? Businesses need people who can turn data science into revenue and that doesn't happen without Data Product Managers.

That makes a great Data Product Manager worth their weight in gold. In this video, I'll explain what Data Product Managers do and what skills you need to make the transition.

I offer courses to help make your career recession resilient. Learn more at DataScience.vin

There's more content on Sbustack: https://vinvashishta.substack.com/

title: More Layoffs Are Coming. Here Are The Companies Laying Off Next And How You Can Prepare.
description:
43 tech companies laid off 11,000 employees in just 8 days. Unfortunately, there's a lot more to come. We are at the beginning of this layoff cycle and cuts are moving beyond tech companies.

Who is next? In this video, I break down what's happened this week and what it means for your job. I cover companies that just announced layoffs in the coming week. I explain which industries and businesses will be shedding jobs soon.

Finally, I explain how to develop a layoff checklist. That includes fixing your resume and profile, building a support network, and finding a few companies to land at if the worst happens.

Playlist link: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLHqWgN37wvd3lyqHoUFQfemGOykzsT0_C

I offer courses to help make your career recession resilient. Learn more: https://www.datascience.vin/

There's more to explore on Substack: https://vinvashishta.substack.com/

title: Recession Proofing Your Data Career: Picking A Safe Industry
description:
Data professionals have several ways to protect their careers from the coming downturn. Choosing an industry that won't feel the impacts of the economic downturn is the most significant.

I explain which industries are most and least stable so you can make an informed decision about where to focus your career.

I offer courses to help make your career recession resilient. Learn more: https://www.datascience.vin/

There's more to explore on Substack: https://vinvashishta.substack.com/

title: 3 Things That Make It Easier To Break Into The Data Field, Even In This Economy
description:
There’s a trick people have been using to break into the data field. I started to see it about 18 months ago, and now it’s a lot more common. People working to break into the field are getting real-world experience and developing a track record of project success.

In this video, I start with 2 really simple things that will make you stand out from the crowd. Then I get into the 3rd thing, which takes more effort, but it’s worth the work.

I offer courses to help make your career recession resilient. Learn more: https://www.datascience.vin/

There's more to explore on Substack: https://vinvashishta.substack.com/

title: 3 Forces Will Lead To Layoffs At Most Companies
description:
Every company’s layoff cycle is going to be different but what’s becoming clear is most companies will be having layoffs. The average reduction is about 20%.

Knowing the drivers and how layoffs will play out helps you prepare. Getting in front of the coming layoff cycles will put you in a good position to ride out the downturn.

In this video, I talk about the major drivers. I explain how layoffs will play out and who is most likely to be let go.

If you’re facing tough career choices, it’s an excellent time to work with a career coach. I offer 1:1 sessions to help senior++ and leadership-level data professionals create a career plan for the coming downturn. Book your session here:

https://app.squarespacescheduling.com/schedule.php?owner=22867384&appointmentType=category:Career%20Coaching

title: The 1 Mistake That Holds Data Professionals Back From Achieving Their Career Goals
description:
I coach data professionals who have plateaued at the senior level. They want to take the next step into principal/staff/distinguished level roles, but can't break through.

For most, the barrier is a holdover from our early career. The habits and mindset that get us to the senior level are not the same as the ones we need to get to the next level. I'll explain the mistake and what to do about it.

There is more content for you to explore on my Substack:
https://vinvashishta.substack.com/

And check out my website to learn more about what I do:
https://DataScience.vin

title: 7 Data Science Truths Changed My Career...And Might Change Yours
description:
I've been in data science for over 10 years. A handful of realizations made a huge positive impact on my career and contributed to my success. That's great. I just wish someone had told me sooner.

That's what I will do for you in this video.

There is more content for you to explore on my Substack:
https://vinvashishta.substack.com/

And check out my website to learn more about what I do:
https://DataScience.vin

title: How Do I Produce Content So Quickly? I Have A System That I'll Teach You.
description:
Being a creator takes a lot more time than it should until you develop a system. Blog posts used to take me a week. With my system, posts take 2-4 hours each. I can ship a YT video in an hour or 2. LinkedIn posts take 10-15 minutes to write.

Here's how I squeeze a lot of content creation into a small number of hours so I can have a day job and a life.

There is more content for you to explore on my Substack:
https://vinvashishta.substack.com/

And check out my website to learn more about what I do:
https://DataScience.vin

title: Feeling Stuck In Your Data Job? Here Are 3 Things You Can Do.
description:
Spending 40 hours per week and feeling like you aren't getting anywhere? A lot of data professionals feel the same. When work starts to burn you out, something must change, but what?

In this video, I give you a framework to help you create a plan. I also give you 3 options for improving your situation.

There is more content for you to explore on my Substack:
https://vinvashishta.substack.com/

And check out my website to learn more about what I do:
https://DataScience.vin

title: How Do You Get Business Acumen and Domain Knowledge While Learning Data Science?
description:
Business acumen and domain knowledge are gap skills, and very few data professionals have them. At every stage in your career, business acumen and domain expertise will set you above others, giving you more opportunities for advancement and new roles.

How do you get those capabilities while learning data science? In this video, I give you several ways to learn both. I also cover how to choose a domain to focus your learning on. You can find all the lists and a detailed write-up here: https://vinvashishta.substack.com/p/how-do-you-get-business-acumen-and

I offer courses on data strategy and value-centric data science. Learn more: https://www.datascience.vin/

title: Why Do Data Presentations And Data Driven Initiatives Fail? It's All About Behaviors.
description:
Why do people fight data so hard? Why do they put more effort into rejecting data than it would take to adopt data-driven methods? There are deep behavioral roots that cause people to reject data.

In this video, I explain the 2 biggest behavioral elements we fight against and how to successfully work with people to help them adopt data-driven methods.

I offer courses to help make your career recession resilient. Learn more: https://www.datascience.vin/

There's more to explore on Substack: https://vinvashishta.substack.com/

title: Early Career Coaching Series Part 2: Career Strategy
description: Most people are used to going from goals to career planning. There is a critical step between those, career strategy. A plan creates a single path to success. A strategy creates multiple pathways to success. A career strategy informs decision-making under uncertainty and in changing times. It allows you to discover new opportunities and create opportunities to accelerate your career. In this video, I walk you through the process of building a career strategy.

title: Early Career Coaching Series Part 1: Goal Setting
description: A coach gives you a different framework for goal setting. You are used to setting goals with your employer but this is a more substantive process. I will help you build out the motivations and drivers that will stay with you throughout your career.

title: Early Career Coaching Series: Introduction
description: Early in your career, before your 5 year mark, you may not have access to experienced mentors and coaches. I built this series as 1on1 coaching sessions. This is the advice and guidance I would give you in a series of sessions to help build your career on solid footings. Go through them in order and make sure to do each exercise before moving on to the next one.

title: The Unwritten Secrets Of Successful Technical Presentations And Conference Talks
description:
There is a lot more to giving a successful talk than content alone. We all understand that but what makes a talk stand out? What gets speakers invited back?

I have spoken at conferences for over a decade. By watching some amazing speakers, I picked up what they do to stand out from the crowd. Here are the secrets they showed me to build an excellent talk.

title: Professional Savagery: How To Tell Someone To Go To Hell Without Getting Fired
description: The reality of the business world is not always kind or friendly. Professional savagery helps you stand up for the teams you lead and yourself. Using a few of these tips once or twice a year will keep you from becoming the corporate doormat.

title: 7 Career Mistakes I Wish I Hadn't Made And The Career Moves I Wish I Had
description:
We only tell a small part of our career stories. Everything you see on social media is roses and rainbows. The most important stories for us to tell are about the rest of the journey.

We all make career mistakes. Failure is an essential part of the process. Mistakes move us forward even while setting us back. Your career will move faster if you make new mistakes instead of the ones everyone else makes.

So learn from what I did wrong in the first 10 years of my career. Make the moves I wish I had. Getting past the rookie moves allows you to make and learn from expert mistakes. That will move your forward faster.

title: What Is AIOps And Why Should A Data Scientist Care?
description:
AIOps is a growing area of investment so it will be resilient in the coming slow down. If you are looking for a safe haven, this is a good one. There are interesting problems to solve including some of the most advanced concepts our field is dealing with like human-machine teaming which I explain a little in the video.

AIOps covers automating the growing sprawl of IT workflows. It is so much bigger than I knew when I started looking into AIOps. In this video, I break down data sources, challenges, complexity, and some of the biggest companies in the AIOps space.

title: What Is High ROI Data Science And Who Am I?
When Should You Work With A Recruiter?
description:
Recruiters are a controversial topic. On one side are excellent recruiters who make the job search easier and get you set up for success.

On the other side are recruiters who will waste your time and might even disqualify you from a job you really wanted.

Your job search success depends upon you being able to know which recruiters to work with and which ones to avoid. So how do you find high-quality recruiters?

In the first minute of this video, I give you one of the best ways to separate quality from trashy. Then I dive into details, red flags to signs of someone worth their weight in gold for your job search.

title: The Fastest Path From Software Engineer To The Data Science Field
description:
Software Engineers make the transition into the Data Science field harder than it needs to be. There is a shortcut that leverages your current skills and requires the least amount of additional learning.

The hardest way to learn Data Science is by taking a ton of classes. The easiest way is hands-on experience working with a Data Science team.

In this video, I reveal an easier way to break into the field that leverages your strengths. I explain what skills you already have, give you an outline of the skills you need, and talk about how you will use them in your new role. At the end, I give you a few recommendations to start your learning journey.

title: New Rules For Breaking Into Data Science In A Changing Economy
description:
Companies are changing their Data Science project mix and that impacts hiring. They are also tightening their budgets and hiring fewer interns and entry-level roles. Competition is increasing for those roles, but most people applying haven't figured out that their resumes and independent projects must adapt.

That's your advantage. In this video, I'll explain how the hiring market has changed and what capabilities are most important today. I give you a few independent projects to take advantage of Data Science project trends.

Follow my advice and you'll stand out from a crowded field. The economy is changing and the people breaking into Data Science who adapt will thrive.

title: The 1 Thing Your Resume Must Have To Get Hired During A Downturn
description:
I have hired hundreds of people over the last 15 years. The one thing I am always looking for on a resume is the one thing I rarely find. I have 2 piles: phone screen and send a "Thank you for applying, but we've decided not to move forward with your application."

Once you understand why we hire, you will have a much easier time building a resume that gets noticed even as the job market tightens. I will explain the language to use and reveal the most essential capabilities hiring managers are looking for now.

title: Do You Know How To Compete For Budget So Your Data Science Team Doesn't Get Cut?
description:
Businesses are tightening their budgets which means Data Science teams must change the way they select and justify their projects. In this video, I explain the impacts of slowing growth. We need a way to show that Data Science initiatives return more value than alternatives. Different organizations within the business will be competing for smaller and smaller budgets. Data Science teams who don't know how to justify their projects will face cutbacks.

I have been preparing students to thrive in the current downturn. This video is a sample from my course: Business Strategy For Data Scientists. Learn more about the outcomes you can expect from this course and see the complete course outline here: https://www.datascience.vin/business-strategy-for-data-scientists

title: Layoff Warning Signs And What To Do If You See Them
description:
We're going through a layoff cycle that will accelerate in the coming months. It's grim but not as bad as the Dot Com bust crowd predicts. Layoffs are demoralizing when they come out of nowhere but there are always signs.

In this video I explain:

What I'm seeing that points to more layoffs to come.
How to find a stable company to move to. (3:40)
Warning signs that a layoff is being planned. (6:20)
Signs that happen in the weeks leading up to a layoff, (14:50)
What leaders should watch out for. (19:20)
What to do if you're blindsided. (20:50)

title: Does Machine Learning Work? Nope. Here's Why.
description:
Machine learning doesn't work and that introduces a fundamental difference between software and models. Software is built on logic. Step 1. Step 2. Step 3. It works every time, at least it does when I'm writing the code.

Models are different because they function. When processes are too complex for logic to cover every variation, we must use models. They do more than software can but there's a tradeoff. Models don't cover every edge case and behave unpredictably.

In this video, I explain the difference and why it's important. I cover Data Science concepts in a way you won't find anywhere else. Subscribe to my substack newsletter and get access to over 200 posts covering topics that are too often overlooked.

title: Can Elon Actually Open Source Twitter's Algorithm And What Would That Look Like?
description:
Open-sourcing Twitter’s algorithm isn’t what most people think it is. I don’t think even Elon Musk or most people at Twitter really understand where this process goes. There may be an ‘It turns out self-driving is a really hard problem to solve’ moment coming.

The code is not very insightful. The model itself is too complex for people to understand and interact with. So, what does open-sourcing the algorithm look like?

It’s the ability to click on a Tweet in your timeline and get a detailed explanation of why it was served to you. There are levels of model explainability.

The most straightforward explanations revolve around high-level user behaviors. I frequently engage with Ken Jee and Harpreet Sahota’s content, so I get served tweets they retweet and like. I follow the topics ‘data science’ and ‘sneakers,’ so I get served a lot of content from those topics.

Diving deeper is much more difficult. Out of all the sneakers-related posts, why was I served this one? I’ve never engaged with that specific account, and I don’t follow it closely, so why did the recommender algorithm serve me that tweet?

Does the recommender love this tweet because it was popular, or is this tweet popular because the recommender loved it? Socrates asked, ‘Whose bias do ya’ll seek?’

This will be a tougher conversation regarding political content and topics far more sensitive than sneakers and data science. I hope Elon and Twitter take the hard road instead of a superficial solution. Euthyphro’s Dilemma is one of our field’s biggest challenges.

When models become actors in human systems, they change the governing dynamics. We must create a framework of acceptable influences, or people will never trust models enough to adopt them for high-value use cases.

title: Advice To Make The Mid Career Transition Into Tech Easier For People 35-45+
description:
I think the hardest part about making a mid-career move into technology is the thought of starting again on the ground floor. You don't have to, and it is actually easier if you don't. How can that work?

You are not a junior-level employee. Your technical skills are, but everything else about you isn't. That's one reason it's so hard to land your first role. The people interviewing you don't see someone who fits the junior employee paradigm.

In this video, I talk about how to showcase your career differently. Your resume needs to tell a cohesive story. Your transition into the field needs to make sense to an outsider. You need to be in the right rooms with the right people. Hint: it isn't a junior-level interview. Finally, you need to create your own opportunities.

title: The Worst Advice On LinkedIn
description:
There's some great advice on LinkedIn and some REALLY terrible advice. Groupthink can make all of those inspirational quotes and influencer content feel empowering. 

Many reinforce toxic traits. Some people send readers down the wrong path just for likes and engagement. In this video, I call out the worst examples I found in my feed this week. I'll explain what's wrong and how to avoid getting pulled into the lunacy.

title: Strategy+Data Science In 2 Minutes: What Are KPIs And OKRs?
description:
The business needs goals and ways to measure progress towards those goals. KPIs and OKRs create a framework for business-wide goal setting. In this video, I explain what they are and how they work.

Interesting in learning more strategy specifically for Data and Analytics professionals? Check out my courses here: https://highroidatascience.teachable.com/

title: Strategy+Data Science In 2 Minutes: Assessing The Size Of A Business Opportunity With TAM, SAM, SOM
description:
The business is looking for growth in the form of new sources of revenue. How do strategists assess the potential size of an opportunity? One way is to start with the customer.

Assessing the market size helps businesses make strategic decisions about pricing, product features, branding, marketing, and a lot more. In this video, I explain a common framework for assessing market size.

Interesting in learning more strategy specifically for Data and Analytics professionals? Check out my courses here: https://highroidatascience.teachable.com/

title: Strategy+Data Science In 2 Minutes: Using The SWOT Framework To Sync Data Science With The Business
description:
Breaking down silos and aligning Data Scientists with the rest of the business means translating our work into business terms. There's a simple way to do that.

SWOT: Strengths, Weaknesses, Opportunities, Threats. I'll explain how to quickly assess the team in business terms. From there, you can connect the team with core business strategy. Communicating with other business units and senior leadership leverages the SWOT analysis so conversations use their language.

title: Friday Fast Takes: Why I Love The Strategy Mindset
description:
It's Friday, so takes get faster. Let me explain what a strategic mindset has done for me in 40 seconds.

Interesting in learning more strategy specifically for Data and Analytics professionals? Check out my courses here: https://highroidatascience.teachable.com/

title: What Peloton's New Strategy Can Teach Us About The Role Of Data Scientists In Business Turn Arounds
description:
Peloton is working hard to turn their business around, including becoming more data-driven. As Data Scientists, we play a critical role in helping companies improve after a setback. Our part makes the business more efficient and opens up new opportunities for revenue growth. I explain how in 3.5 minutes.

Interesting in learning more strategy specifically for Data and Analytics professionals? Check out my courses here: https://highroidatascience.teachable.com/

title: Strategy+Data Science In 2 Minutes: How Much Strategy Do Data Science Leaders Need To Know?
description:
Data Science leaders are responsible for managing part of the business's value creation process. Here's how much a leader must understand to succeed.

Interesting in learning more strategy specifically for Data and Analytics professionals? Check out my courses here: https://highroidatascience.teachable.com/

title: Strategy+Data Science In 2 Minutes: How To Get Resources For Projects And Infrastructure
description:
You have to understand how to explain your request in terms of value. Otherwise, the senior leadership won't buy-in. Learn how in just 2 minutes.

Interesting in learning more strategy specifically for Data and Analytics professionals? Check out my courses here: https://highroidatascience.teachable.com/

title: Strategy+Data Science In 2 Minutes: 3 Main Components of Strategy and How Data Scientists Help
description:
There are 3 main components to every strategy: Business model, operating model, and technology model. Data Scientists help the business define all 3. Here's how.

Interesting in learning more strategy specifically for Data and Analytics professionals? Check out my courses here: https://highroidatascience.teachable.com/

title: Why Is Business Strategy Important? Without Strategy, Data Science Is Setup To Fail.
description:
I teach strategy because I learned early in my career, any technology fails to thrive without a connection to strategy. I built a new definition for business strategy to explain how technology fundamentally changes strategy.

The two cannot exist without each other. As Data Scientists, we play an important role in strategy. 

First by using data to help the business understand itself.
Next we provide senior leaders with inference from business systems models to help them make better decisions.
Finally, we identify new opportunities for growth.

We cannot do any of that, if we don't understand strategy. Senior leadership and the Data Science team end up speaking different languages. They speak value. We speak technology and tactics. Strategy is the link between the 2.

I teach Strategy For Data Scientists to bridge the gap. Sign up here:
https://highroidatascience.teachable.com/p/business-strategy-for-data-scientists

title: An Example Of Data Visualization For Data Communications
description:
Data communications, using inference for education and impact. I rarely get a quality data visualization to share. This simple visualization from the National Weather Service hits all the main points.

This is a quick walk through of the main points any data communication must hit. I explain how this visualization checks all the boxes.

title: The Impact Of Multiple Ontologies On Data Science
description:
Diving deeper into ontologies from my recent Substack post on what's next in Data Science. The way our field manages the interactions between models and people will have significant consequences.

In this post, I give a brief explanation of ontologies, how they are used in Data Science, and the implications of multiple, conflicting ontologies.

Link to the Substack post: https://vinvashishta.substack.com/p/data-science-trends-for-2022

title: Data Literacy: The Dangers of Digital Metaphors For People Learning About Data Science
description:
Non Data Scientists need to understand how the technologies our field uses work. They learn from traditional educational institutions, online learning, and from companies that use teaching as part of their sales process.

All 3 groups use what Eric Chown, a professor at Bowdoin College, calls Digital Metaphors. Students need a point of reference for new concepts. Digital Metaphors are powerful tools which help people connect the new concept with something familiar.

In sales and marketing, the objective is to help the student understand how the technology will work for them. The objective is to help the student make an informed buying decision.

In education, the objective is to help the student understand how the technology works. The Digital Metaphor is a starting point and content gets more detailed from there.

The danger of just learning the Digital Metaphor is the false confidence it gives people. We feel like we understand what the technology does for us and so we also understand what it does, even though we don't.

This is an important framework to evaluate what we understand about a technology and what we need to understand so we can do our jobs effectively.

title: New Data Science Consulting Rates. What Should You Charge As Demand Increases?
description: I answered this question about 6 months ago but the marketplace has changed significantly. In this video I break down rates by tiers across Data Scientist, Data Engineer, and Machine Learning Engineer consulting roles.

title: What Is The Metaverse And Why As A Data Scientist Do You Care?
description:
The metaverse already exists in many ways. Even though the term is new cool, the concept is quite old. Many companies have already built the frameworks for metaverses, aka the multiverse.

When we walk away from the hype of a new term, these existing pieces and their product roadmaps give us an idea of what the pragmatic metaverse looks like. In that view, Facebook is more of a challenger than an innovator.

Machine Learning becomes infrastructure for the metaverse. Without models, supporting virtual experiences at scale is impossible. Blending real world and virtual experiences is impossible. Creating and supporting economies is impossible. There's a lot more work to be done by our field in this space.

Machine Learning is a critical component of the metaverse. It's a new career path for us which will open interesting opportunities. It is worth getting to know the applied metaverse. The pie in the sky pieces, not so much.

title: Is Now A Good Time For Mid Career Data Scientists To Make A Job Move?
description:
With so many open roles available to you, should you think about testing the market? For mid to senior level Data Scientists, now is an excellent time to evaluate opportunities and your current role.

In this video, I talk about how to evaluate your situation and new roles. Companies over the next 1-3 years will fail. Those who cannot adapt to the new competitive marketplace, much of it driven by technical capabilities, will soon be terrible places to have just transferred into.

You can quickly find yourself in a much worse place than you left. Well respected companies will begin to suffer so how the company is doing today is less important than evaluating where the company is going.

As companies fail, layoffs will reduce the number of open Data Science roles and increase the number of Data Scientists competing for high quality roles. You are in a good position now to make a change and set yourself up for stability during the next few years of uncertainty.

title: There Is No Such Thing As A Data Science Learning Path That Will Get You A Data Science Job
description:
I know you want a learning path to land a job but in Data Science, the learning path is just the beginning. Companies are looking for you to have a process. You must learn how to take a business problem and end up with a reliable model, that works in production, and produces business value.

Bootcamps to degrees teach skills and workflows. The process is harder to teach because it requires you to synthesize skills to problems you've never seen before. It is best taught through experience and working with a mentor over a year or 2. Education isn't setup to do that. The project assignments are great at reinforcing the workflow but fail to develop your process.

You have to abandon the straight line concept of a learning path to be successful in landing your first role. Focus on the outcome and learn the process, agnostic of tools. The programming language, model architecture, math, etc. are only supporting pieces. You need them to execute your process. Without the process, you don't really understand how to generate the results.

title: Ethics in Research
description:
This video is designed to identify and discuss potential ethical issues that can impact on research in information and communication studies. This is a guide but ultimately the responsibility for decisions made during the research process is yours. Be sure to remain open and honest about your research. If you are engaged in an academic research project discuss issues with your supervisor. If your project is work-based use your line manager as your mentor whenever possible. What you must never do is attempt to ignore or dismiss possible problems; they will not go away and you are ultimately responsible for everything that happens during your
research investigation.

title: Defining Research
description:
Now we have developed a theoretical framework for the research from the literature review; the next step is to use that theoretical framework to construct a conceptual framework. title: Financial Data with Python
description:
Financial Data
This section works with a locally stored financial data set in the form of a CSV file. pandas provides a number of different functions and DataFrame methods to import data stored in different formats (CSV, SQL, Excel, etc.) and to export data to different formats.

Descriptive Statistics
Statistical analysis methods are often based on changes over time and not the absolute values themselves. There are multiple options to calculate the changes in a time series over time, including absolute differences, percentage changes, and logarithmic (log) returns. 

Resampling
Resampling is an important operation on financial time series data. Usually this takes the form of downsampling, meaning that, for example, a tick data series is resampled to one-minute intervals or a time series with daily observations is resampled to one with weekly or monthly observations.

title: Candlestick Plot with JNJ & COVID Timeline
description:
We more forward with candlestick charts by looking at JNJ data together with the COVID 19 pandemic timeline.

The candlestick chart is a style of financial chart describing open, high, low and close for a given x coordinate (most likely time). The boxes represent the spread between the open and close values and the lines represent the spread between the low and high values. Sample points where the close value is higher (lower) then the open value are called increasing (decreasing).

title: Introduction to Arrays with p5.js
description:
An array is a list of variables that share a common name. Arrays are useful because they make it possible to work with more variables without creating a new name for each one. This makes the code shorter, easier to read, and more convenient to update.

When a program needs to keep track of one or two things, it’s not necessary to use an array. In fact, adding an array might make the program more complicated than necessary. However, when a program has many elements, arrays make the code easier to write.
